segments.text: Okay, we're talking to Dr. Owen Gingrich.
It's working and it's fine.
You know, we've talked before, and of course the title of this book is The Great Copernicus Chase, and I'm really fascinated about, and by your fascination, with this one book.
And of course you give me a lot of background in the essay in here, but tell me a little bit, I mean, why is it so important for you to find not only every copy, but to try and determine...
the people who read it through the centuries, actually.

Well, there was a challenge thrown out by Arthur Kessler in his The Sleepwalkers, in which he has entitled a section, The Book Nobody Read, and describes Copernicus's book as the all-time worst seller.
And I started out on the project assuming that was more or less correct, and it turned out, over a period of years,
evidence was piling up that that was a very wrong view of things, and so it wasn't that I set out to prove Arthur Kessler wrong.
It's just how it worked out.
Doing something like that gets a momentum of its own.
I started out by knowing that we were going to celebrate the 500th anniversary of Copernicus in 1973, and he had been
examined for so long, it seemed to me that it was going to be hard for me to add anything new to it.
So, I had this incident in Scotland, or on my way up to Scotland, talking with a colleague who was also on the planning committee for the Copernican celebrations about
Well, maybe there are more people alive today who've read Copernicus's book in these great book programs than in all of the 16th century.
And we thought maybe we could count on the fingers of two hands the people who have read the book intelligently than the very next copy of the book I found, which was in the Crawford collection.
And that's something I thought was very much missing from your book, one of the great
the greatest private library established in the last century was the Lindeciana, and you say practically nothing about it.
We're writing another book so we can redress our earth.
Okay.
Throw it out so that you can do it.
If you want to digress a little bit, tell me a little bit about it and what else.
I'll pick up this other story later then.
Lord Crawford, who is one of the leading earls of
Scotland, started in as building a book collection, and then his son, and I think that's the 26th Earl, became more and more taken up with this, and they established a truly incredible library.
But the 26th Earl was also an amateur astronomer.
And his observatory was better outfitted than most professional observatories could afford to be in those days.
So, he had a wonderful collection of astronomy books, and he was rather dismayed when it was decided not to reappoint an Astronomer Royal of Scotland, in part because the person who had been in
that position so long had been very ingenious, but in the end became more and more interested in pyramidology and a few things like that, and he brought some level of disrepute to the position.
But Lord Crawford decided that he would give all his instruments and his astronomy book collection to Scotland, provided there
Well, he didn't put any provisions in.
He gave the whole thing with just a little note.

The implication was, and he was busy talking this up with the Secretary of State and others, the implication was, you better, you know, make sure that we have a national observatory in Scotland, and here's the nucleus for doing it.
So, these books constitute a fabulous astronomical collection, and
But the rest of their collection, which is in multiple volumes in the Bibliotheca Lindeciana.
And that is where?
It is, well, there are various volumes that commemorate it, but the collection has been broken up.
For example, the Oriental Manuscripts, which was a fabulous collection, have gone to
the Rylands Library and formed the basis for their Oriental collection.
That was part of that original purchase that Mrs. Rylands bought?
That was the Spencer collection.
That was the Spencer.
I understand that, but I thought there were some components given, donated by Lord Crawford.
They had sort of the world's leading collection of Bibles for some time.
But eventually, the collection got dispersed.
So I think they were coal and iron magnates, and when the market sort of collapsed, they sold off some things, including their Gutenberg Bible.
But originally, that was part of the collection.
The present Lloyd Crawford has still got a remarkable collection of Bibles, but it doesn't have some of those high spots anymore.
So, to get back to the train in Edinburgh.

I went up there to, since I was going to Edinburgh, I stopped in at the Royal Observatory to see the Crawford Collection, which at that time was kept in a couple of large safes, sort of three deep in the books.
It was, they were not easy to see, but basically these books had been just on the open shelves
all the way up through World War II.
And then they decided, wait a minute, these books are much too valuable to be out here in the open.
And the incredible thing is, as far as I know, they never lost anything.
That's truly amazing.
But I looked at the Copernicus book, and this first edition was annotated from beginning to end by somebody who clearly knew what he was doing, and it seemed to me completely unlikely that if
So few people had read the book, the very next copy I would see would be so well annotated.
So, I really scratched my head on that one, and then decided that in some incredible way, this was the copy of one of the ten people we had mentioned, and that's how it turned out to be.
It was the copy of Erasmus Reinhold, who was the preeminent
astronomer teacher in the generation following Copernicus.
And so he was working this book through very carefully, and he set into motion a whole tradition of teaching about Copernicus within the Lutheran university system.
Reinhold was at Wittenberg, the central Lutheran place.
I decided at that moment that, aha, here is something I could do
which might cast some further light on Copernicus, which nobody has done.
Namely, look at a number of copies and see what kind of annotations are in to get an idea of how people were looking at the book and how they were studying it in the 16th century.
And of course, this presupposes your own expertise.
This is not something for a layman scholar, a researcher to do.
I mean, you have to bring tremendous baggage to this kind of
You have to appreciate what these annotations are.
You have to be able to.
Well, this was the beginning of a long learning experience, which started right there at the Royal Observatory.
Namely, it had a blind-stamped pigskin binding and no name in the book.
I was really hard put to figure out whose it was.
And then I saw the initials, E-R, stamped in the binding.
And I said, aha, Erasmus Reinhold.
So I grabbed a piece of paper to make a rubbing.

And when I made the rubbing, it came out E-R-S, which at that moment deflated me, because I was so naive, I had no clue that the way people stamp their names in books was not only their name, but where they're from, Erasmus Reinholdus Salveldiensis, his hometown.
So, it was all right for Reinhold, but that was the first thing I learned about
16th century bookbinding.
And then I had eventually to learn about heraldry in order to decipher book plates, and I had to learn about watermarks and about how to distinguish bindings and so on.
It was quite a whole series of
bookish things I had to learn.
So what precisely would you say you learned from these annotations?

In the Reinhold copy, what I discovered was that he was terribly interested in the details of the planetary mechanisms and not at all interested in the cosmology of throwing the earth into motion and fixing the sun in the center, which is what we consider the great breakthrough of Copernicus's work,
And that was of secondary importance to Reinhold, who liked the idea that Copernicus had eliminated one of the Ptolemaic mechanisms that he considered unaesthetic.
So it was a totally different way of looking at it, and it turns out that this is absolutely vital for understanding what was going on in the acceptance of the Copernican theory in the 16th century.
Namely, it wasn't until the very end of the century with Kepler and Galileo that people began to say, hey, guys, this is a real system.
This is how the physical world really is.
This isn't just playing mathematical games.
So in a very real way, this copy of this printed book provided a window for you, didn't it, into the thought and the thinking of that time?
Absolutely.
How often can something like this happen?
The supreme irony is that the first book I saw was the best.
In searching for over 500 more copies, which I've looked at, there isn't another book that matches it in terms of insights and quality.
But that's not to say there weren't lots of other interesting surprises along the way.
Well, I mean, of course, you were spoiled by this first one.
What other things did you think that you might have been able to find, what you're hoping you might find?
Well, at the outset, you would expect at least some people to say, this crazy, mixed-up guy is throwing the whole world out of kilter.
But you don't get comments like that.
The closest you get is a series of comments in the margin that say, here, Copernicus is dreaming, or here he's hallucinating.
And it turns out that these...
have to do with some of his trigonometric proofs, where Copernicus neglects the fact that there's ambiguity in certain trigonometric solutions of triangles.
Let me show you what I mean.
If you have a side and an angle and an opposite side, there's a double solution, you see.
if this is the opposite sign.
So that's picked up from a commentator who says that about Copernicus, and a fair number of people copy that into their books.
But you don't find the criticism with respect to the heliocentric cosmology.
Sort of the
The really interesting thing about the annotations is that major annotations very rarely come singly.
That is to say, a major astronomer putting major annotations in his book is liable to have one or more students who copy those notes into their own books.
So if you find some major annotations, you're likely to find them again in another book.
And then another fascinating set of annotations are the corrections put in as a result of the Inquisition's instructions in 1620.
And because they were very explicit about four places, sorry, a dozen places for censoring the book, if you look at a book, you could immediately say yes or no.
Was this book censored or was it not?
So I now have very good statistics on this, which the Inquisition never knew.
They got something over 60 percent of the books in Italy, and essentially none outside.
This is fascinating, isn't it?
So, really.
You probably saw that.
I think there is the map in this book on the.
That's quite a nice book, by the way.
I just got a dandy review of it.
There's people who are apparently still reviewing it, where somebody said, it's a great book.
You don't have to read it in order.
People have said that about my book, and I take that as a compliment.
You say you've actually sought out and located 500 approximately?
Here's the map you see on page 109, okay.
Where you see the censored copies and the black dots, and there's a more updated version of that map.
It'll be in my
So this is a living book for you.
I mean, this is actually a perfect example of a book that actually resonates truly from the time of its first appearance through the generations, doesn't it?
There's actually a history not only of the text that was written, but each individual copy has been influential.
I mean, is that a fair statement?
Well, that's right.
It's influential in actually looking physically at the book as opposed to seeing
a copy of it and looking at the text.
If these were all like peas in a pond, there's no reason to look at all of these copies.
I mean, it would be, I think, very dull to start looking at copies of Darwin's Origin of Species.
To begin with, it's in a trade binding, so they are all alike unless they've been rebound or something.
And people aren't typically annotators anymore, the way they were
in the 16th and 17th centuries.
So I would not expect, excepting very rarely, to find interesting remarks in the margins.
And with Darwin, you have, you know, a couple thousand.
Well, by the time you go through all the editions, you've got tens of thousands of copies of the book.
So trying to find the ones that are annotated by looking at all of them would be a foolhardy thing.
You mentioned in here that only two or three books have undergone this kind of scrutiny.
The First Folio of Shakespeare, the Lutenberg Bible.
I suppose we could include the base psalm book.
There are only 11 or so of them.
And Copernicus.
The Elephant Folio of John James Audubon is a wonderful book.
Somebody is redoing the Shakespeare folios at the moment.
I've had some correspondence with him.
In terms of technique, I guess?
Yeah, in part, swapping notes on what one can find or expect to find about provenances, for example.
And do you think that there will be annotations in the folios?
No, he's not finding much at all like that.
Do you have an explanation for that?
Well, it's basically not the kind of thing you, it's not a technical work that you would want to write clarifying comments in the margins.
Also, I think the destruction of the Shakespeare folios has been considerably greater.
You estimate that actually half of the Copernicus .
It was appreciated as an important book early on.
It's very interesting, something I found rather recently, and it's coming out in, I believe, the next issue of the Harvard Library Bulletin.
It's an issue that you will find interesting, because the editors have asked quite a number of people to write very short essays on Widener Library as I
a seat for detective solutions.
In other words, using the library to solve particular problems.
I'm a member of the Friends, and I think they send that to the library.
They should, yeah.
So, I've mentioned some of this research, and I mentioned finding something like seven or eight major libraries in the 16th century in England.
Out of those, you get something like six copies of Copernicus, which shows that anybody who's building a major library is quite apt to have this book.
The one where it doesn't occur is one that is strictly a legal library, so it wouldn't have been a target book for him.
But otherwise, it seems to be, you know, already by the late
1500s, it's seen as a classic book, and people aren't going to throw it away, because it was an expensive book, and it was sufficiently technical, it doesn't get worn out.
So, tell me, how did you go about locating these books?
Did you take out ads?
Actually, almost so.
I have put little notes in the bibliophile journals, so that dealers or
collectors could see I was doing it and to get in touch with me.
But you have to do it, first of all, by using the sort of standard bibliographic tools.
Then you look at the nature of libraries in the world of learning, for example, when the library was founded and how many early books they have.
And on this basis, you write a lot of letters to libraries asking if they've got it.
You slip up on things.
A few years ago, somebody said, you know, you ought to inquire in Solitern in Switzerland, because that's the kind of library that should have this.
And I said, well, I don't have a copy listed there.
I'll write them a letter.
I wrote them a letter, and they said, sorry, we don't have the book.
But six months later, the librarian wrote and said, guess what?
We've found the book in the uncatalogued portion of our library.
Isn't that amazing?
I was so pleased that he remembered.
And then it turned out that it had a sufficiently interesting note in it at the beginning that we spent some effort trying to decipher the handwriting and transcribe it for the census.
And so are you planning to publish this census?
I'll show you some pages in just a moment.
All right.
But the chasing around to find the books has been quite tricky.

There's the Adams catalog of sixteenth-century books in Cambridge University libraries, but I had to be there for a number of months before I discovered that Trinity College had a copy that wasn't on the Adams list.
I'll talk about that copy in the Groyer Club lecture, probably.
Are you confident that you found most of the
Well, not all of them.
I wonder how many are out there that I haven't found.
I would like to think that it's fewer than 20 copies of the first edition, but I just don't know.

I recently, somebody had told me some time ago that he thought there was a copy in Manila, and I thought, well, yeah, it's likely the Jesuits would have taken it in, so I wrote to the Jesuit University, and they said, nothing doing.
And then, just a couple years ago,
And the information got more specific.
It was at a Dominican university.
So you did find it.
And I have, even a former student has gone in and taken a photograph of it, so it's physically there.
And how about locating private owners?
That must be a lot trickier.
Private owners is a lot trickier, and for this, I am practically dependent upon dealers, to tell me, who
they know of who's a private collector who would be apt to have it.
There tends to be a little bit of secrecy.
If a person is an active client of a dealer, a dealer is very hesitant to mention this because they don't want other dealers poaching.
But the irony of this, again, is that it always seems that the other dealers know who this person is, and they're always glad to tell me.
So there isn't too much
keeping of secrets in this business.
Now, the garden copy, which you maintain, is really probably the most important in private hands.
Where did that go, just out of curiosity?
Where did that go from the garden?
That has gone to Vicenza in Italy, and I am on my way over to have another look at it.
So it really only changed hands once since leaving the garden?
That's right.
And this is a private collection?
Yeah, quite a fabulous private collection.
He has, in fact, made a catalog of his collection.
It's sitting here on the shelf.
Is this somebody I might like to interview when I go to Italy, do you think?
You might very well want to.
Could I have a copy?
Would you imagine by having a copy of this?
I could give you a copy of that, or I could...
give you a copy of the front page of his catalog.
That would be even better, which is here.
Well, as you can see, it's just a wonderful Xerox edition.
Oh, yeah.
Isn't that nice?
He did it rather beautifully.
His name is
If I could have a copy of that.
I think this or the letter will enable me to get in touch with them, too.
I think I better give you the letter.
If you don't mind, and you can count on my discretion.
Yeah, well, I mean, it's better for you to wait, in a way, until after I've been over there to see him, so I get a better sense of how...
I really want to get some European collectors in this next book.
Otto Schaeffer.
Otto Schaeffer.
Is he selling this collection?
He is, but it doesn't matter.
I'd still like it.
Another one is Henri Scheler.
Have you met him?
No.
I'm really going to try and get some of the really notable references.
I am going to Italy to see Umberto Eco.
Okay.
Well, when are you going to Italy?
I haven't planned it yet, but it'll be several months.
We'll wait until I'm back, and then I can tell you a little bit better.
Just so I can put him on my itinerary, projected itinerary.
That'd be great.
Right.
You see, in Europe, because of tax reasons and so on, some people try to be a little bit more secretive about what they're doing.
There's somebody you might want to check in Japan, should you ever get that far.
I hope.
His name, well, is Reverend Kumoy or something like that.
Is he the fellow that got the Lincoln stuff and the Shakespeare folios?
I don't know.
Did he form a university?
No.
He has a, he's putting them at a Buddhist monastery.
Reverend, what's his name once more?
I think it's K-U-M-O-I or something like that.
Uh-huh.
He has a Copernicus.
And I just asked about a, asked Jonathan Hill about, uh,
the catalog of Arago, of his library.
He's a Frenchman from last century.
I asked him if he still had it.
Was Copernicus listed in it?
He says it's, you know, in Kyoto, with Reverend Kumoy, I'll fax him.
So, he's busy buying.
Fascinating.
So, this is a book you've seen several times before, and yet you're going to see it again.
Oh, I'm going to see it because of the entire collection.
I'm not basically going to see the Copernicus book.
And this, of course, is a bibliophile in you.
Well, I've been chasing another book as well, which is the Appianus Astronomicum Caesareum, and he's got a copy of that, which I haven't seen.
Now, tell me a bit about that.
I've seen a hundred, over a hundred copies of that one.
Well, you see that picture on the wall?
That's not a picture.
That's an actual page.
of a book that has got layered parts on it.
There are about ten layers of paper there because it's a moving device, and this was the great tour de force of printing in the 16th century.
And who is the author of this?
His name is Apianus.
And we spell that?
A-P-I-A-N-U-S.
Well, 25 years ago,
Addition Leipzig in then East Germany put out a fantastic facsimile of this book.
You can see it's large, a full cap of lining.
Is that a facsimile?
That's the real thing.
Son of a gun.
The book is full of those kinds of things.
What happened was I was helping a dealer who had two defective copies that he was merging to try to get one good one.
And he had doubles on this particular page.

So a book was not really... And so he asked, you know, I said, you know, I'd really like your duplicate of this one, because he had only enough pages, really, to make one, almost to make one good book.
So I have one of the very few single pages in captivity of that book.
Were there, and when was this book published?
Oh, wow.
And all of that coloring was done in the shop in Ingolstadt, in his private press.
Most books at that time were, of course, hand-colored by the owner.
This was one of those rare editions where if you bought this book, you got a colored one.
Is the Copernicus illustrated at all?
Were there any illustrations in there?
Oh, lots of technical diagrams.
We would touch probably every summer.
Yeah.
This is one that has an interesting history.
It's been cut up by somebody who is busy making good books out of bad ones.
So it's, in fact, not even quite in order here.
Here's the famous page with the heliocentric diagram on it.
Wow.
Isn't that, but it hasn't really fucked that badly either, has it?
No, it's a, uh, it's an incomplete copy.
As I say, I own, uh, 1.9 copies of this book.
I have a complete one, but I have, uh,
I don't have a first edition, which is now about $150,000.
I saw Jack Pincus's copy out in L.A.
a couple years ago.
Okay.
Yeah, the nice one.
And, of course, Haskell Norman considered that's a great feeling of his collection, that he was unable to get a Copernicus.
Well, as you know, there's one listed in his catalog.
Well, that was the one that was stolen.
Yeah, that stolen copy was here in my office for about six weeks.
I was part of that story of finding out what was going on.
I don't know how much you want to impress me about the Copernican census and when you want to actually start looking at some books.
Okay.
How about just, we've got about a half an hour before you have to go back again.
I do want to actually impress you a little bit more.
So you started a new census on this book, and you hope to find out similar things from this book?
No, I only call the other one a survey rather than a census, because I haven't copied down provenances and all the rest.

But what happened was when Addition Leipzig made this facsimile, it was a tour de force of color printing, including the wrinkles, the stains, everything, excepting then they botched it up when it came time to assemble the moving parts.
So this was just
totally bungled, and I got interested in this facsimile, and then from the facsimile, got interested in seeing what their chances were of getting a bungled copy to reproduce.
And it became clear pretty rapidly that all of the copies that left Appianus's workshop were just impeccably assembled, magnificently so, and that the only copies that were messed up
were ones that had come apart because of dampness, and then pages got shuffled and so on.
I got into the Basel University Library on a Saturday afternoon, when there were no librarians around, and found their copy was all messed up.
So, I carefully reconstructed it for them, with a little trepidation, because you can never be sure
how librarians are going to feel about this kind of thing.
But in that particular case, they seemed to be very grateful that I had done it.
The British Museum copy, they were, was restored at the beginning of this century, dreadfully mixed up.
They were not about to let me move the pieces, but they took me down to the conservation
And I didn't touch them, but I pointed to them piece after piece, telling the conservators where they had to put them.
And so I essentially reconstructed the British Library copy without actually touching it.
Wow.
Would you say this became an obsession of yours, or would you say that you saw this as part of your professional mandate, or was this a hobby, or is this something you did to move yourself?
You almost have to say it's a professional hobby if there's anything like that.

So I have gone to considerable effort to see every possible copy that I can when I find out where one is, but it's not such an obsession that after an auction I knock myself out to find out where it has gone and so on.
So I know a number of copies that have passed through the auction market where I haven't a clue where they've gone.
Of course, with the Copernicus, I've worked very hard on this.
I had an interesting story one day.
Most book dealers are pretty forthcoming about where copies are, but Hans Krauss was typically a very secretive man.
So, finally, he agreed to tell me something about the copies he handled.
So, I went down to New York, and he produced the card file of all of the
Copernicus copies he had handled, but without any locations on them.
So, I went through his entire stack of cards, and I told him where each one was.
Then, when we were through, I said, where's the Prince of Lichtenstein copy?
You've sold that one, too, and it isn't here.
What did you say to him?
Well, he was pretty much faked out.
I think I melted him, because after that— Melted was the word?
Melted, yes.
uh, obviously had a grudging admiration to what I had achieved.
That's a great story.
So, did he know where, did he have an answer?
They hadn't kept a record?
He didn't know.
Wow.
It was a second edition.
Well, have you found it since then?
Most of the Prince of Liechtenstein materials have book plates in them.
I've not found one with a book plate.
So, that one's, you don't know?
I suspect I may have seen it without knowing that it was.
It could have been rebound or anything.
Yeah, but you pretty much also determined provenance as many of the books as you could.
That's right, and I don't have a Prince of Liechtenstein provenance on any copy.
Let me tell you something that's happened more recently.
That's a great little story.
I had heard a rumor that Columbia University Library had sold one of their second editions as a duplicate.
I heard some, you know, vague rumor that it had gone to Japan.
the two leading Japanese dealers denied any knowledge of it.
And so, I wrote to Columbia, and they, after some months, wrote back and said, oh, it had appeared in the Swan book auction sale at such and such a day.
Well, I knew right away that I knew where that copy had gone.
Well, why hadn't I recognized it?
And you know what?
In that process,

That book had been rebound, and all the earlier provenances destroyed, which as soon as I knew that piece of information, I was delighted to discover that the two times I had measured the book came out exactly the same to the nearest millimeter.
So, that was a check on your own procedure, wasn't it?
That's right.
And the rest of the things, like the red speckled edges, was not changed in the rebinding, so it was
It was clear that, yes, indeed, this was the same one.
That is, as far as I know, the nearest I've come to having a ghost in the same sense.
Can you think of any other books that might warrant this kind of determined investigation, not necessarily books in your professional line of perspective?
I suspect that it works better for technical books, and I think Kepler's Astronomia Nova would be another good candidate for this kind of work.
Otherwise, it's a little hard to say.
I don't think literary books are apt to draw the same kind of marginalia.
And Ulysses, for instance, to cite one example, which certainly had great consequences, as publication did.
I'm sure that nobody wrote into the margins of those books, because they recognized the value of it immediately when it came out.
That would be my guess.
That's my assumption.
Somebody is trying to do a census about Ulysses, I think.
Yeah, it'd be interesting perhaps to locate them, but I don't think looking in for marginalia is necessarily going to help.
And so, to go back to the original premise, Kessler's mandate, was it, that this is a book that nobody read?
That's totally, in your view, you've disproven that.
It seems to me that it was recognized as very important early on, and
If you stop to think about it, it's got to be wrong.
There was a second edition and a third edition.
So demand was there.
If it's an all-time worst seller, you do not have a second edition and a third edition.
So why would Tesla make such a bold statement like that?
Probably he couldn't penetrate it.
Who knows?
That's right.
Well, on this particular general area, he has preserved a certain amount of mythology.
Okay, I know you're kind of scheduled.
No, I'm still okay, but I must show you some pages of the census.
Let me bring some.
Okay.
Here you can see the camera ready copy on its under way.
This shows the physical state of the book, then the provenances, if there are any, and then
any comments about what's going on in annotations in the book.
Who will publish this?
Harvard?
It's, at the moment, we're expecting it to be published by Brill in Holland and Leiden.
Okay, now you're looking at the, at a section of USA.
So, there you, there it begins with... How did Arizona get one?
That's interesting.
They had some collectors living out there, the Barkas's.
I think they're still alive.
So you never know, do you?
You even have the prices there.
Oh, I have a lot of prices in.
Wow.
Where possible.
Going way, way back.
Here's the bankrupt's copy.
Here's the pinkest copy.
Look at all the information you have on that.
Yes, that's because there's a lot of material in it.
Now, for instance, let me just read aloud.
On the last flyleaf is a Greek inscription with a Latin paraphrase, apparently not from a classical source, followed by six Latin lines as follows.
And there's a long Latin inscription.
